gmd:organisationName.gco:CharacterString: National Atlas of the United States

gmd:metadataStandardName.gco:CharacterString: ISO 19139 Geographic Information - Metadata - Implementation Specification

gmd:title.gco:CharacterString: Indiana Myotis distribution in North America: North America, 2003

gmd:organisationName.gco:CharacterString: National Atlas of the United States
Angela E. England, Bat Conservation International, Inc.

gmd:abstract.gco:CharacterString: This map layer portrays our current understanding of the distributions of United States and Canadian bat species during the past 100-150 years. Specimen and capture data were obtained from a variety of data sources, including U.S. State natural heritage programs, Canadian conservation data centres, published literature, unpublished reports, museum collections, and personal communications from university, federal, State and local biologists. Records are all specimen, roost, capture, or positive visual identification-based; no acoustic-only identifications were used for this map layer. This map layer reflects minor changes to the July, 2002, data set.

gmd:purpose.gco:CharacterString: These data are intended for general prediction of possible presence of the species within a broad geographic area. Actual presence of the species can only be accurately known by actual field surveys conducted in a variety of seasons. No responsibility is assumed by Bat Conservation International or the National Atlas of the United States in the use of these data.

Although these data have been processed successfully on a computer system at the U.S. Geological Survey, no warranty expressed or implied is made by the U.S. Geological Survey regarding the utility of the data on any other system, nor shall the act of distribution constitute any such warranty. No responsibility is assumed by the U.S. Geological Survey in the use of these data.

gmd:title.gco:CharacterString: The Mammals of North America, Volumes I and II

gmd:environmentDescription.gco:CharacterString: Microsoft Windows XP Version 5.1 (Build 2600) Service Pack 2; ESRI ArcCatalog 9.0.0.535

gmd:supplementalInformation.gco:CharacterString: Due to confidentiality agreements to protect sensitive roosts, exact localities may not be released, at the discretion of Bat Conservation International data administrators. Additional information about these maps may be found at <http://www.batcon.org/>. The distributed compressed file includes individual polygon files for 45 bat ranges, as well as a point file indicating the location of isolated bat sightings.

gmd:organisationName.gco:CharacterString: Earth Science Information Center, U.S. Geological Survey

gmd:contactInstructions.gco:CharacterString: In addition to the address above there are other ESIC offices throughout the country. A full list of these offices is at <http://ask.usgs.gov/esic_index.html>.

gmd:fees.gco:CharacterString: There is no charge for map layer.

gmd:organisationName.gco:CharacterString: Penn State Institutes of Energy and the Environment

gmd:measureDescription.gco:CharacterString: No tests for logical consistency were performed on these data. The data used to create this file were collected over a 100-150 year period. No attempt has been made to separate historical from current distributions. A positive record does not necessarily imply current residence of the species. Records may represent either resident, migratory, or stray status. Not all areas have been surveyed or reported on as completely as others, so there remain gaps in the data used to compile the original occurrence file. As more fieldwork is completed and reported upon by researchers in these sparsely-known and sparsely-reported areas, future updates of this map layer should improve in these areas.

This map layer contains information on bat distribution for the 50 United States, the District of Columbia, and the 13 Canadian provinces and territories. No data were collected on bats of Puerto Rico or the U.S. Virgin Islands. Species distributions within Mexico are shown only for bats which also occur in the United States.

Literature sources, museum experts, and other contributors were relied upon for identification of species. Data are accurate to the best of originator's knowledge. Data compilation and checking were done manually; there is a possibility that some errors remain. Mexican data were collected to different standards, therefore the distributions shown for Mexico are not as accurate as for the U.S. or Canada.

Due to the variety of sources used, there was varying accuracy in the way bat records were reported. Some of the reports were as latitude and longitude, UTM, or public land survey system coordinates. Some locations were given as a number of miles in a direction from a nearby town or landmark. Others were reported as just a mountain, park, or waterway. Each location was digitized to the nearest hundredth of a geographic degree as a single point based on the best description provided. If no specific location was reported more accurately than county level, the point was digitized to the center of the county, rounded to the nearest twentieth of a degree of longitude and latitude.

gmd:description.gco:CharacterString: For each species, BatLoc was buffered with a 15-mile radius around each point locality, using the MapInfo software. The buffered data were overlaid on digital maps of Bailey's Ecoregions of the United States, Major Land Resource Area (MLRA) boundaries, the United States, Canada, and Mexico. Records near possible edges of each species distribution were scrutinized, and visually compared to MLRA and ecoregion boundaries. Previously published regional and species-authority maps were consulted, and bat working group and colleague input was compared. Records of single bats (non-colony, nonmultiple-captures) that were greater than 75 miles distant from most other points were not included in the main range polygon(s), and were indicated as separate points within the range files. Points were also used for records that were considered questionable by local experts. In certain regions where few data are available, as well as for species which are not well known or easily captured, colleague feedback was especially relied upon. The resulting maps were saved as BatRange.

Bat locality records were gathered from multiple sources, including U.S. natural heritage programs, Canadian conservation data centres, scientific literature publications, unpublished reports, museums, and information provided by university, federal, State, and local biologists. Records are all specimen, roost, capture, or positive visual identification-based; no acoustic-only identifications were used for this edition of the original occurrence files. Each locality record was assigned longitude and latitude values to the nearest hundredth of a decimal degree. Records which were not already geocoded but which had place names were researched using the USGS Geographic Names Information System (GNIS) and the Canadian Geographic Names Data Base (CGNDB) 1997. Records located at various distances from place names were visually geocoded using the DeLorme Atlas and Gazetteer for the applicable State. Records which could not be geocoded with certainty were rounded to the nearest twentieth of a degree, as long as the resulting rounding kept the plotted position within the boundary of the originally reported county. Records only as specific as county-level were assigned a value corresponding to the center of the county according to the GNIS, rounded to the nearest twentieth of a degree. Records were entered into MapInfo Professional version 6.5 GIS software. Fields for each record included species, State, county, geographic details, observations, longitude, latitude, date observed, source type, and source. Points were plotted and visually checked to ensure they plotted in the correct county. The resulting files were saved in the BatLoc database.
The BatRange files were modified to match the National Atlas shorelines, and shapefiles were created.
Extraneous attributes were removed from bat014p020.dbf (Lasiurus cinereus - Hoary Bat) and bat044p020.dbf (Pipistrellus subflavus Eastern Pipistrelle).
Electronic map of broad habitat types, used to understand where species distribution lines might be corresponding with landscape characteristics.

gmd:description.gco:CharacterString: Database of point location files which were used to create BatRange.

gmd:otherCitationDetails.gco:CharacterString: Due to the sensitivity of bat roosts to disturbance, actual locations of many of the data are considered confidential. BCI is unable to release actual locations to the public, so these files are not published in the usual sense of the word.

gmd:organisationName.gco:CharacterString: Sources for these data are numerous. They include federal, State, local and university biologists; museums; heritage data centers; and published and unpublished reports.

gmd:otherCitationDetails.gco:CharacterString: The sources for these data are too numerous to list here. However, detailed information on each bat record is available from Bat Conservation International at the address listed in the contact information.
